comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Quality angry eyebrow work from the dog strangler. I suspect she (he? hard to tell with the prevailing fashions for tiny tots) is a victim of force majeur and would have been just as happy to make a cash settlement.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] And too early for Swallows and Amazons. That's what I get for focussing on freckles! Had missed the beautiful lettering on the boat...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] That can't be it; It says the badger was a brig and that is clearly a sloop. I think it far more likely that he called it Badger because it has a pointy nose.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] The kid had an imagination but not enough pocket money.Nelson would still have been hero of the day.

comment.author: 80456351@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I was going to remark that it's so impressive that the dog held still, and then noticed the puppy-strangler. The photo seems really crisply in focus.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/la_belle_province] Have you ever seen (what I think could be) a watch fob worn around a woman's neck like a locket? Wondering if it belonged to her father/brother/some male relative...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] She's english - you wouldn't know what strange customs they have. I was assuming it was a locket. Are you guessing fob watch from the heavy chain? She seems to have a separate fob watch at the apogee of her bosom.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I did notice the other fob chain, but still think the chain around her neck is very heavy for a locket.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] A quick google image search for "victorian heavy chain locket" shows a lot of lockets like that. If I knew more about technical terms in jewellery I could probably find a decent match.

Edit: Mind you, locket pendant watches seem to have been a thing too, so it could easily be one.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I'm still slightly hoping for a tale of a brother lost to fever while collecting cochineal beetles along the upper reaches of the Orinoco River, but if you want to ruin that for me, you just keep on searching those jewellery sites...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: One of the buildings in this other Poole photo has Fannings Provision Stores written on the front, also a J. fanning & Co. is listed at 10 O'Connell Street Waterford in Egan's 1894 directory.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Paul, drove myself crazy trying to work out why I'd tagged that one as Fannings. "Swept it" for notes, but missed yours. Thanks.

Fair chance it might be these Fannings? I'd love to tie this Mr Fanning down to a Butter Store. Has to be important, or how he was known locally, as that was written in Poole's Day Book...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/] J . Fanning, butter & egg exporter is mentioned in the Irish Law Times & solicitors Journal under adjudications in bankruptcy, more then likely the same man as in the photo above I would say. books.google.com/books?id=TNIQAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA453&d...

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content:
I wonder is Mr. Fanning adopted?

FANNING
Will of Joseph FANNING, Solicitor, Waterford, dated 1.9.1835:-
all to wife Kate FANNING alias GIBBONS "for our dear little children __n Henry FANNING and William FANNING; Henry DOWNES and John MEADE (?) Executors.
Probate to widow 4.10.1835.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Taking a semi intelligent guess...:) These small barrels were called Firkins.. www.webexhibits.org/butter/history-packages.html

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Ah, sorry - wasn't being pedantic! The barrels in your Poole photo link are sealed very differently to these Firkins in New Tipperary, that's why I wasn't assuming butter...

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: This is the Fannings house in Newtown according to the NLI catalogue. I think a good candidate is a house called Weston that is still standing, unfortunately only the roof is visible on Google Streetview but it seems like a good match. By the way my great grandmother was a nanny at Weston when she met my great grandfather who was a coachman for a Quaker family who lived across the street, they were married in 1888. My great grandparents on their wedding day, July 28 1888 at Rockville, Newtown

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Hi, I was looking at that earlier but thought after looking at the OSI that Weston didn't look quite right in plan. I thought that it may have been Newtown Park, a bit north, as the map shows a more simple building with porch and basement moat..

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: I have to agree the plan view does not quite fit although its possible the house was added to between when the photo was taken and the publication of the 25" map. Newtown Park seems a little too close to the river I think. This view is from the gardens of the Fannings house and looks roughly North East I would say, you can see the river in the distance.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] Hard to know. Any chance it could have been Suir Ville? terraced garden steps etc? This article mentioned it having being extended in 1895. Also the south corner of Suir Ville on OSI shows an L shaped structure that would match the roof of the building seen behind the Fanning house photograph. Anyways, Not bad for an Egg and Butter man?

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Think I've found it Tin of Beans, I believe its View Mount House. It seems there were two J. Fannings, one lived in Newtown and was a butter & egg merchant, the other man, J. H. Fanning, a spirit merchant according to Egan's guide, lived in Farranshoneen where View Mount House is located. I think J. H. Fanning is our man.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: That L shaped structure is a glasshouse. www.buildingsofireland.ie/niah/search.jsp?type=images&...

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: My moneys on View Mount, Suirville is similar but not quite a match I think. View Mount house is almost identical to the one in the NLI catalogue even down to the basement windows the flat roofed addition at the back of the house and the moulding over the ground floor windows. Only thing missing is the portico.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] That's it. Well done. The distance from the river is also more plausible. maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,662916,610733,6,3

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Just looking at the 1901 Census for Newtown Road, J. Fanning the provision merchant is at number 17 which I believe back then was further down near De La Salle College. If you look at some of the neighbours and their occupations I think its clear they were not as wealthy as the people in the photo above. I think there might have been a little confusion in the cataloging of some of these photos, for instance the photo of what looks like Mr Fannings store is called out as Mr Fanning Newtown Group.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Also the building returns list house No 17 as a 2nd class house which View Mount surely wouldn't have been.The only house (no 21) on the Dunmore Rd listed with 7 windows 'to the front of house' on the building return is occupied by a Patrick W Keily. Looks like J H Fanning had left by 1901.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: I believe I found his widow here, she is listed as a wine merchant but at 72 seems to be too old to be the lady in the group photo above.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/33577523@N08] There are three people on the steps of the "Fanning House" photograph. An old woman in black sitting and one of the others is in servant clothes. No children!! This must be the widow Fanning you found in the census. I don't think that the above picture was taken outside this house. The background detail doesn't fit the architecture. Looking at our original J Fanning house No 17 return it can be seen that it is next to a school.( No 16 Christian Brothers). The house "Swiss Cottage" fits this location.OSI Swiss Cottage. Have a look at the buttress on the far right of the above picture streetview buttress and the double sashes on the mews.streetview double sash I'm assuming the sashes might be the same on the main residence. National Inventory

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: -----------------AH HA !!! ------------and our Mr John Fanning above was a Ship's Captain According to Mr Poole FANNING, John b. Waterford 1874 028406 Liverpool 1901 vol. 62 1902-1903; vol. 77 1904-1911-- from Lloyd's Registry of Ships Captains.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03/] Well done on finding the house! Its still there next to Waterpark College although not much can be seen from the street. So it seems there were three J. Fannings and probably some confusion in the cataloging of the photos at some stage.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: Although the John Fanning at Swiss Cottage does say he's a provisions merchant. Possibly a retired captain with a fondness for fresh butter and eggs. A mystery.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Seems I jumped the gun a little, only two J. Fannings then. As you said possibly a retired sea captain or one who combined his nautical skills with the export of butter & eggs.
